title.narrative: Envelope 2- Enhancing resilience of conflict-affected communities in Jarablus and A'zaz by improving water supply systems including water stations to secure clean, sufficient, and adequate water for drinking and hygiene purposes.

description.narrative:
More than ten years of conflict, economic degradation, and persistent displacement has exposed millions of people in North West Syria to ongoing shocks and deprivation. This proposed project is a mixed ERL and WASH approach to enhance resilience and strengthen the humanitarian response.
The project aims to achieve the following outcomes: 1. Enhancement of social cohesion among IDPs and host community members as well as activate communities’ engagement in the project planning, designing, and monitoring. 2. Improved accessibility of all HHs to clean, sufficient, and adequate water for drinking water in communities and their surrounding camps.
The interlinked ERL and WASH activities have been developed in coordination with the ERL, and WASH Clusters to ensure the project is integrated with ongoing and planned works to increase resilience in targeted locations.
The project will increase the resilience of HHs in Jarablus and Aghtrin communities and their surrounding camps with mixed ERL and WASH activities to improve the accessibility of all HHs to clean, sufficient, and adequate water for both drinking and hygiene purposes through rehab and improving the capacity of the one existing drinking water station implemented by IYD previously on Euphrates River located in Jarablus community as well as the one existing drinking water stations in Aghtrin community constructed by IYD through another project. The water station in Jarablus will be supported with needed rehabilitation works, including but not limited to graveling, paving, establishing a fence, and providing the station with a monitoring system by installing a camera system to prevent any potential robbery. While the two stations in Jarablus and Aghtrin will be supported with hybrid energy systems
Finally, under this project, two Community Engagement Teams (CETs) will be established, one per location, to operationalize and mainstream social cohesion, and enhance the communities' participation in the project's implementation. Overall the project will directly benefit 84,018 living in targeted communities and camps in Jarablus and A'zaz sub-districts.
